message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and echocardiography findings suggest a congenital heart disease called transposition of the great arteries, where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched in position. This is caused by an abnormality in the spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate a congenital heart defect, specifically transposition of the great arteries. This occurs due to a failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral properly during embryonic development. The other options are not associated with this specific condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and echo findings suggest that the newborn has transposition of the great arteries (TGA), where aorta arises from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle. This is caused by abnormal spiraling of aorticopulmonary septum during development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and echocardiography findings suggest the patient has a congenital heart defect called Transposition of the Great Arteries, where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched. This occurs due to abnormal spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart defect, specifically transposition of the great arteries, which is caused by a spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development. Separation of tricuspid valve tissue from myocardium causes tricuspid valve dysplasia or Ebstein anomaly. Fusion of endocardial cushion causes atrioventricular septal defect or complete, rather than partial, anomalous pulmonary venous connection. Division of aorta and pulmonary artery causes aortic coarctation or pulmonary atresia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of vessel arising from the left ventricle and bifurcating immediately, along with the low oxygen saturation, suggests transposition of the great arteries. This occurs due to abnormal spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during development, resulting in the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has a congenital heart defect, specifically tetralogy of Fallot. This condition involves four abnormalities, one of which is a misaligned aorticopulmonary septum, resulting in abnormal blood flow and mixing of oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood. Option D is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The immediate bifurcation of the vessel arising from the left ventricle indicates Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). TGA is caused by the abnormal spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development. This leads to the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle, causing inadequate oxygenation. The other options point to different developmental processes that do not result in TGA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s condition indicates Tetralogy of Fallot, which is caused by an abnormality in spiraling of aorticopulmonary septum during fetal development. This causes unequal division of the aorta and pulmonary artery, leading to oxygen-poor blood being pumped to the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the vessel arising from the left ventricle and the vessel emerging from the right ventricle suggests that the patient has transposition of the great vessels (TGV). TGV is caused by the spiraling of aorticopulmonary septum, which results in the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle. This abnormality prevents oxygen-rich blood from being pumped to the body, causing cyanosis.
